newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Cambodian forces closing in on opposition town.
newsitem.headline: Cambodian forces closing in on opposition town.

text.p: Cambodian government forces on Monday advanced to within one kilometre (half a mile) of the last town held by loyalists of ousted First Prime Minister Prince Norodom Ranariddh, military officials said.
But Khmer Rouge rebels, who had come to reinforce the royalist positions at the town of O'Smach, said they had pushed government forces back to Phong, a town 12 km (seven miles) south of O'Smach.

The Khmer Rouge also said they had destroyed a government artillery base and had killed 70 soldiers in a nearby town, Krong Kriel, about 25 km (15 miles) south of O'Smach. They said only three rebels had died.
But General Meas Sophea, chief of fighting operations, denied the Khmer Rouge's reports of their advance and government casualties and said his army was only one km from O'Smach.

"We expect to take it today," he told Reuters, adding that dense forest, a proliferation of landmines and booby traps and malaria in the area had slowed the government's advance toward the northwest town near the Thai border.
The general said about 600 Khmer Rouge troops were fighting alongside Ranariddh's forces.
The area around O'Smach was quiet on Monday after forces loyal to Second Prime Minister Hun Sen pounded the town with mortar and artillery fire at the weekend.
Dozens of artillery and mortar shells landed four to five km (three miles) from the centre of town and two shells landed on Thai soil over the weekend.
Ranariddh's rag-tag forces have been fighting the government in the northwest since the prince was overthrown by Hun Sen in Phnom Penh on July 6.
The Khmer Rouge on their clandestine radio on Monday appealed to opposition forces to press the fight against Hun Sen.
Major Yen Bunsrun of Ranariddh's army said his forces were fighting with help from more than 1,000 soldiers of the Khmer Rouge, Maoists who ruled Cambodia during the 1975-79 "Killing Fields" years.
"The Khmer Rouge are responsible for the front-line fighting, laying landmines and blowing up a bridge," he said.
Ranariddh's forces control a small strip of territory along the Thai border leading to the Khmer Rouge base of Anlong Veng, about 50 km (30 miles) east of O'Smach, Cambodian army officials said.
Yen Bunsrun said the Khmer Rouge had joined the royalist fighters out of fear that if O'Smach fell, government troops would then press into Anlong Veng.

Hun Sen and Ranariddh formed an uneasy coalition after 1993 elections sponsored by the United Nations. The Khmer Rouge was a party to the 1991 pact that led to the polls but reneged on the deal and waged a low-intensity guerrilla war against Phnom Penh.
Ranariddh had been negotiating a peace deal with the guerrillas for several months and was reported to have reached an agreement just before Hun Sen's power grab.
The fighting has pushed thousands of fleeing civilians to the Thai border, and the Thai army has been moved to full alert in case the fighting spilled across the border.
Major General Jeerasak Promakorn, commander of the border task force in Thailand, said he thought the royalists could hold out for some time.
He said the Thai army was allowing international relief agencies to cross the border up to 200 metres into Cambodia to assist displaced persons.
Cambodians might be allowed to cross the border if fighting worsened, he said.
